subject: Critical Thinking
title: Parliamentary Debate: Structure Meets Substance
description: A micro-lesson that makes Parliamentary Debate: Structure Meets Substance usable.

hook.text: In the British Parliament, members literally face each other â€“ two sword lengths apart. The structure forces opposition.

buildup.text: Parliamentary debate: a format with Government (proposition) and Opposition. Each side has set speaking times and roles.

discovery.text: Roles: Prime Minister opens, Opposition Leader responds, each side has 2 members.

twist.text: You don't choose your side. In competitive parliamentary debate, you're randomly assigned Government or Opposition.

climax.text: This is the deepest lesson: if you can argue for something you disagree with, you truly understand the'ssue.

punchline.text: The best debaters can argue any side. That's not dishonesty. It's understanding.

quiz.question: Why does parliamentary debate often randomly assign sides?
options: To force debaters to understand and argue any position, building deeper understanding
